details.reused_text: President Vladimir Putin says Russia will refuse to sell oil to any country that imposes the Westï¿½s ï¿½stupidï¿½ price cap on its oil.

Moscow ï¿½ Russia, the worldï¿½s biggest exporter of energy, could cut oil production and will refuse to sell oil to any country that imposes the Westï¿½s ï¿½stupidï¿½ price cap on Russian oil, President Vladimir Putin said on Friday.

ï¿½We will think, maybe, even about a possible, if necessary ... reduction in production.ï¿½

Putin, who rules the worldï¿½s second-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia and the largest gas exporter, said Russia had a production agreement with other members of the Opec+ oil producersï¿½ club, so such a drastic step was still only a possibility.

Selling oil and gas to Europe has been one of the main sources of Russiaï¿½s foreign currency earnings since Soviet geologists found oil and gas in the swamps of Siberia in the decades after World War 2.
Putin dismissed the Westï¿½s attempt to squeeze Russian finances, saying the $60 price cap corresponded to the price at which Russia was selling oil.

President Vladimir Putin says Russia will refuse to sell oil to any country that imposes the Westï¿½s ï¿½stupidï¿½ price cap on its oil.

Moscow ï¿½ Russia, the worldï¿½s biggest exporter of energy, could cut oil production and will refuse to sell oil to any country that imposes the Westï¿½s ï¿½stupidï¿½ price cap on Russian oil, President Vladimir Putin said on Friday.
ï¿½As for our reaction, I have already said that we simply will not sell to those countries that make such decisions,ï¿½ Putin told reporters in a news conference in the Kyrgyz capital, Bishkek.

ï¿½We will think, maybe, even about a possible, if necessary ... reduction in production.ï¿½

Putin, who rules the worldï¿½s second-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia and the largest gas exporter, said Russia had a production agreement with other members of the Opec+ oil producersï¿½ club, so such a drastic step was still only a possibility.
Putin dismissed the Westï¿½s attempt to squeeze Russian finances, saying the $60 price cap corresponded to the price at which Russia was selling oil.
ï¿½It all boils down to about this figure,ï¿½ Putin said.
The Kremlin chief cautioned that attempts by the West to impose a price cap would lead to the global collapse of the oil industry and then a catastrophic rise in prices.
The Kremlin chief cautioned that attempts by the West to impose a price cap would lead to the global collapse of the oil industry and then a catastrophic rise in prices.
ï¿½All this will lead at some stage to a catastrophic surge in prices and to the collapse of the global energy sector.

Moscow ï¿½ Russia, the worldï¿½s biggest exporter of energy, could cut oil production and will refuse to sell oil to any country that imposes the Westï¿½s ï¿½stupidï¿½ price cap on Russian oil, President Vladimir Putin said on Friday.
The Group of Seven major powers, the EU and Australia last week agreed a $60 per barrel price cap on Russian seaborne crude oil after EU members overcame resistance from Poland.
Putin dismissed the Westï¿½s attempt to squeeze Russian finances, saying the $60 price cap corresponded to the price at which Russia was selling oil.

Russia will not sell oil to any country that imposes a price cap on its oil exports and is considering reducing its oil production, President Vladimir Putin says.
On Monday, the Group of Seven, European Union and Australia imposed a price limit on Russian oil of $60 per barrel in a move aimed at reducing Moscowï¿½s ability to finance its war in Ukraine.

Putin said Russia has no mandate to launch a preventive first nuclear strike, unlike the US, but Russiaï¿½s advanced hypersonic weapons would ensure Russia could respond forcefully if it ever came under attack.
Putin said Russia would likely have to reach a peace agreement regarding Ukraine in the future, but felt betrayed by the breakdown of the earlier Minsk agreements.
Putin said mediators Germany and France had betrayed Russia and were now pumping Kyiv with weapons.
ï¿½We will consider a possible reduction in production if necessary,ï¿½ he added, calling the price cap a ï¿½stupid decisionï¿½ that is ï¿½harmful to global energy marketsï¿½.

ï¿½I have already said that we simply will not sell to those countries that make such decisions,ï¿½ Putin said on Friday at a news conference held after a regional summit in Kyrgyzstanï¿½s capital, Bishkek.

A decision on Moscow's response to EU price cap will be announced in a presidential decree within the next several days, says Putin

Russia may cut its oil production in response to the G-7 cap on the price of its crude, President Vladimir Putin said.
After months of planning and negotiations, the biggest tranche of international sanctions on Russian oil took effect on Monday.
ï¿½Iï¿½m not saying now that this is a decision, but if necessary weï¿½ll think about possible production cuts,ï¿½ Putin said.

ï¿½Iï¿½m not saying now that this is a decision, but if necessary weï¿½ll think about possible production cuts,ï¿½ Putin said.

The price cap will not have any negative consequences on Russiaï¿½s revenue as the $60 a barrel threshold introduced by western countries ï¿½corresponds to the prices at which we sell today,ï¿½ Putin said.

Russia may cut its oil production in response to the G-7 cap on the price of its crude, President Vladimir Putin said.
After months of planning and negotiations, the biggest tranche of international sanctions on Russian oil took effect on Monday.

The European Union banned most seaborne imports of the countryï¿½s crude oil, and the G-7 agreed that anyone wanting to access key services that the bloc provides ï¿½ especially insurance ï¿½ will have to pay less than $60 a barrel.

A decision on Moscow's response to EU price cap will be announced in a presidential decree within the next several days, says Putin

Russia may cut its oil production in response to the G-7 cap on the price of its crude, President Vladimir Putin said.
ï¿½I have already said that we simply wonï¿½t sell oil to those countriesï¿½ that participate in a price cap, he said.

The European Union banned most seaborne imports of the countryï¿½s crude oil, and the G-7 agreed that anyone wanting to access key services that the bloc provides ï¿½ especially insurance ï¿½ will have to pay less than $60 a barrel.

There are still enormous unanswered questions that will shape the impact of the measures on the oil market, including the depth of non-European insurance markets, the appetite of some tanker owners to participate in trade with Russia, and exactly how effective enforcement of the cap can be.
